error.notes: in its response to the Commissioner for Privacy and Data Protection the Justice Department argued the worker's complaint should be dropped because it was "lacking in substance". It said the disclosure did not constitute a privacy breach and "was made in good faith and for an official purpose".

external.notes: guard told the convicted sex offender's wife that she was responsible for rejecting a request for their children to visit their father in prison (her name was meant to be protected).

discovery_notes: Leaked documents show the prisoner's wife twice called the DHHS worker's direct line to complain after her husband's application was denied; the woman's superiors stopped her from handling prison requests, cancelled her work phone number, blocked incoming calls from the prisoner's wife and warned the woman to stop calling.
summary: Child protection worker's name revealed to sex offender in fresh privacy breach. A child protection worker is fighting the state government for compensation after an official revealed her confidential identity to a jailed sex offender whose case she worked on.  The former worker alleges the Department of Justice failed to take reasonable steps to protect her personal information when a guard at the Hopkins Correctional Centre gave a prisoner's wife her name and phone number.
